AGENTS.

And bcgg'd moments leave TO speak


With the French General.
The advancing foe an answer made;


But tit was quite provoking)
Not one of them could understand


The language il was spoke in
So there they stood in piteous plight,
Twas ludicrous to see,
Until the Bull-Frogs came insight,


Which sha.ed them nightly.
Then all went home, right glad to save
Their property from pillage:
And all agreed to blame the man


Who first alarm'd the village.
Some were well pleas'd and some were mad,
Some turn'd it off in laughter;
And some would never speak word
About the thing thereafter.
Some vow'd if Satan came at last,


They did not mean to flee him;
But if a frog they ever pass'd,


Pretended not to see him.
TUESDAY, sV0vember 27, 1927.

LEA PUSEY,

From the National InteHigenccr, Nor. 90.


The NORTH EASTERN BouNpARY.--The New
York Albion is paper published weekly in the city
OF New York. the principal objects of which are, to
condense English news for the information of the
Americanized English. and of the American public:
and to present views of British concerns and poll
tics, such are in general accord with the spirit of
The Ministry of Great Britain. This is done tenn
perately and las far as we know bamelessIy in a
foreign spirit to be sure, but in spirit Of general
amity and good will to our country.


In the last number of the Albion, the Editors of
this paper called upon in a manner so earnest.
and in terms so very polite that the call cannot well
be resisted, to state their of the present state
of the controversy between the United States and
Great Britain, concerning the North Eastern Boun
Diary between the territories of the two countries.-


The article in the Albion, to which refer, is in
the following words


NORTH Eastern Boundary. This is daily be-
coming an object Of important. not to say alarming
consideration for the people of both countries and
it is really lamentable to the bad feeling the sub
iect is creating on the lines, and the avdity with
which persons give currency to untricndly and in
furious reports of all kinds. All the difficulty that
has yet taken place. has occurred the territory
now under negotiation between the two governments,
and which il is understood shall remain in the hands
of its present possessors until the subject is finally
settled. Therefore as the territory is, and always
has been, within the sovereignty of Great Britain.
the acts of certain persons. in hosting the Amer-
ran Flag, interceptng the mail, &c are not only
Illegal, but in opposition to the known wishes of the
american Cabinet. The British government has.
at the request of the American. withheld further
grants of lands than those already made; & prohibited
the cutting of timber on the unappropriated lands,
until the result of the negotiation is known Should
not, then. all attempts the part of the citizens Of
the United States. to disturb the sovereignty of the
soil. be discontinued not only with the view Of pre-
serving the friendly relations between the two 60
vernments, but to prevent the unpleasant collisions
the bare recital of which tends excite such unpea
! SAINT feelings :


"If we correct, and we believe we are, that
General Baker was arrested on what is technically
and practically British territory, and that this ter
ritory remains under the jurisdiction of Great Bri
tain bv the right of possession. and by the acques
cense of the American government until the ques
tion to whom it shall ultimately belong, be settled
an article in the National Itelfgencer to this effect
will be productive Of the best consequences. w,
make our appeal to the National Aatelhgencer. from
the accurate means of information it is supposed II
have, and from the high character and respectabilit
always enjoyed by that Journal"


Ne,U York Albion. Nor II.


The question, respecting this boundary, arise
out OF the treaty or FeaCp ol 1855, OctWeen ti'
United States and Great Britain. Being still al
unsettled question, provision made in the treat
OF Client. for ascertaining and fixing the boundary
Under that Treaty, Commissioners were appointe
to settle the question. They were not able to agre
upon an adjustment. In that event. anticipated a
possible by the trainers of the treaty Of Ghent, pre-
vision was made in that compact. that, on a dsa
grecment between the commissioners of the two &c
vernaents, they should report the fact to their re
spective governments, and that the question shnui
thereupon be referred to the umprage Of some So
veregn arbitrator On that subject negotiation
were commenced in London, before Mr. Rnsh's re
turn to the United States, and have been continued
bv Mr.. Gallatin, which are understood to have re
suited in the formation of convention for settling
the premnarcs Of the reference of this question ac
cor'ng to the Treaty of Ghent


This is the history OF the dispute.


As to the matter of fact each party has been in tn
posscssionof some portion of the disputed ground


that is to say the Governments Of Masaachusett
and Maine, on our part, and of the Province q
New Brunswick, ON the part of Great Britain, hav
exercised Jurisdiction over it and each party ha
been dspnsed to strengthen its claim by further act
Of posseesion. In the mean time. between the FL
reign ministers IF the United States and Great Br
tain there has been constant correspondence, q
From the National Lntelligenccr, Nor. %.

mutual forbearance, of the expediency Of the pre-
scrvation of the same state of things in the disputed
territory as existed at the date Of the Treaty Of
Client, and of avoiding all disputes which might
grow ont of the agitation OF it.


With respect to the two governments, there is
perfectly good understanding, upon the obvious pro-
priety, and indeed necessity. Of forbearance and
moderation on both sides. as to this question. Any
acts of contrary character are acts OF individual
citizens, without the authority sanction OF either
government and, Of course, are to be avoided and
rebuked.
This is the general state of the facts. As to the
particular case of Gen. Baker, referred to by the
Albion, we can only say, that if he stopped the mail
and did other obnoxious acts, son what is techni-
cay and practically British territory" by which we
understand such territory was in possion OF Great
Britain at the date of the Treaty of Ghen. and pre-
viously. then he violating what believe to be
the settled understanding between the two govern


ments. and his conduct will, Of course, receive no
countenancc the part of the United States
Whether he was on that territory not, is aques.
tion which depends upon evidence not within our
reach


We hope we have answered the question Of the
Albion satisfactorily. We will only add. that we
believe that measures will be taken, on the part Of


the United States to ascertain the true character OF


the transactions on the disputed territory, there


being disposition here to connIvc at any acts OF


violence, contrary to the understanding which exists


between Great Britain and the United States on this


subject.


| BANKS.--The number Of Banking institutions


in the United States, of all kinds, good bad and IN"


different is $50, (Which add thervarous branches,


and they will amount TO 600. OF this number


eighty are on the list of broken banks. All the Ken


lucky, Tennessee, Illinois, and Missouri banks are


of this class and those of Alabama are but little bet


ter. Maine has 23 banks, of which are broken:
Vermont 81 New w-Hampshre 90; Massachusetts
| II, of which are broken Rhode Island 46, all


good, and we should think good for nothing Con-


necticut l6--2 broken Newly ork 55-7 broken:
New-J ersey 23--4 broken; Pepnsy lvania SLY


broken Delaware tt broken Maryland 25-6


broken District of Columbia 15-3 broken; Vir-
ginia and l5 branches n. and s. Carolina 20;
Georgia Z; OHIO 34-22 broken; Mississippi
Louisiana s and Michigan 2-l broken.


Considering the great number OF these institutions


scattered over the whole country, and using so ma.


ny different modes of engravngs, il is not surprising
that counterfeiting has become SO frequent. One
eighth of the convicts at Auburn, are confined for


this crime. The number of detected counterfeters
is about 24O the amount yearly put in circulation


is estimated at t,oo millions; the loss no doubt falls
principally upon the poorer class. for they are the


least able to detect them; some plan ought therea
fore to be devised to prevent this enormous deficit
in the proceeds of their hard earnings Maine and


MaSSaCHuSetlS nave lot tniS purpose Ie4uileu


banks to use Perkins steel plates, which during the
90 years they have been in use, have never been
I, successfully counerfeed. If the evil can be stay
: ed by the adoption of similar measures in other


states it should not be delayed 1t is at least worth
an inquiry, if not AN experiment.


: INTERNAL IMPROVEMENTS The number and mag
: ntude of the various works OF internal improves


ment strictly so called, canals, railways NC in proc
orosS varinuQ uf thp United


States. is truly astonishing and almost Incredible
:, We will enumerate some of them from memory. -
TO commence with our own state-we have near
500 miles of canal completed, in progress, or proc
o vided for. We have also the Schuylkil navigation,
1903 miles. in full operation; the Union canal. 30


miles nearly completed the Lehigh navigations


say 60 miles. connected with a railway of miles.
s Tributary to our state, have the Delaware and
Chesapeake canal, the Delaware and Hudson canal,
n the Morris canal and preliminary measures have
been taken. for the construction Of railway from
y Columbia to Philadelphia; another from Danvlle to
Il Mount Carbon: and for the connection ct the Sus-
e auehanna with the Delaware. by canal or railways
is or both by the Lehigh There is also. the Cones
D. toca navigation which, we presume, must be near
l. completion and meetings have been held to pro-
D cure the continuation of thePennsylvania cana1o
> from Middleton to Columbia upon the Susquehannas
d In the west, we have the Ohio canal, in forward
J. state. which. when completed, will form line OF
about 500 miles. 1t IS prOposeu aiso' rs our iea-
ers have lately been informed, to connect this by
cross canal with the Pennsylvania canals. In the
SOUTH the Baltimore and Ohio railroad is in progresss
O and strenuous exertions are making to commence
: the Chesapeak and Ohio canals. Each of these


works are Of immense magnitude. In Virginia. there


is canal, and more have been projected in
c South Carolina.


The steps which have been taken towards the con-
= sructon of railroad from Camden. opposite tha
If city. to South Amboy and the erection OF the Del.
e aware and Raritan canals, have been recently laid

II" Oto Co'ohy 1hte-.J0nhden on 1dct.
WHEN these free states were colonies
Unto the mother nation,
And in Connecticut the good
Old Blue Laws were in fashion,
A circumstance which there occur'd
And much the mind surprises
Upon rehecton) then gave rise
To many strange surmises.
You all have seen, as presume,
Or had chance to see
These strange amphibious quadrupeds,
Call'd Bull-Frogs commonly
Well, in Connecticut 'ts said


By those who make pretensions
To truth, these creatures often grow
To marvellous dimensions.
One night in July '5s


They left their home behind 'cm,
Which was an oak and chesnut swamp
About FIVE miles from Windham.
The cause was this the summers sun
Had dried their pond away there
So shallow, that, TO save their souls,
The Bull-Frogs could not stay there.
SO, in regiment they hoppd,
With many curious antic,
Along the road which led unto



The river Minnomantic.
Soon they in sight of Windham came,
All in high perspration,
And held their course tow'rd the same
With loud vociferation.
You know such kind Of creatures are
By nature quite voracious
Thus they, compell'd by hunger, were
Remarkably loquacious.
Up flew the windows one and all,
And then with ears erected,
From every easement gaping rows
Ofnight-cap'd heads projected.
The children cried, the women scream'd,
60 Lord have mercy on us
The French have come to burn us out,
And now are close upon u.s."
A few, upon the first alarm,


Then armed themselves TO go forth
Against the foe, with guns and belts,
Shot, Powder-horns, and so forth.
Soon all were running here and there,
In mighty CONSERVATION,
Resolved of the town to make


quick evacuation.
Away they went across the lots,


Hats, caps and wigs were scatter'd,
And heads were broke, and shoes were lost,
Shins bruis'tl and noses batter'd.
Thus, having gain'd mile or two,


These men ofsteady habits,
All snug behind an old stone wall,


Lay like nest of rabbits.
And in this state, for half an hour,


With Jaws an inch assunder,
They thought upon their goods at home,
Expos'd to lawess punder.
They thought upon their helpless wives,
Their meeting house and cattle,
And then resolved to sally forth


And give the Frenchmen battle.
Among the property which they


Had bro't with them to saveit,
Were found two trumpets and drum,


Just as good luck would have it.
Fifteen or twenty iewsharps then


Were found in good condition,
And all the longest winded men


Were put in requlslton.
Straichtway, in long and loud alarm,


Said instruments were clang-ed,
And the good old one hundredth psalm


From nose and jewsharp twang-ed.
Such as we're armed in order ranged,


The music in the centre,
Declar'd they would not run away,


But on the French would venture.
There might have been among them all


Say twenty guns or over
How many pitch-forks, scythes and Halls


never could discover.


The rest agreed to close the rear,


After some intercesson-
And all together made queer
And curious procession.
Some were persuaded that they saw
The band of French maranders,
And not few declared they heard
The officers give orders.
These words could be distinguished then,
Dyer Hellerkln, and Fete ) ;,
And when they heard the last, they though


The French desired treaty
Co three GOOD sober minded men

From the Providence Gazette.
THE FROGS OF WINUEFANr.

full articles.article:
And bcgg'd moments leave TO speak


With the French General.
The advancing foe an answer made;


But tit was quite provoking)
Not one of them could understand


The language il was spoke in
So there they stood in piteous plight,
Twas ludicrous to see,
Until the Bull-Frogs came insight,


Which sha.ed them nightly.
Then all went home, right glad to save
Their property from pillage:
And all agreed to blame the man


Who first alarm'd the village.
Some were well pleas'd and some were mad,
Some turn'd it off in laughter;
And some would never speak word
About the thing thereafter.
Some vow'd if Satan came at last,


They did not mean to flee him;
But if a frog they ever pass'd,


Pretended not to see him.

bv Mr.. Gallatin, which are understood to have re
suited in the formation of convention for settling
the premnarcs Of the reference of this question ac
cor'ng to the Treaty of Ghent


This is the history OF the dispute.


As to the matter of fact each party has been in tn
posscssionof some portion of the disputed ground


that is to say the Governments Of Masaachusett
and Maine, on our part, and of the Province q
New Brunswick, ON the part of Great Britain, hav
exercised Jurisdiction over it and each party ha
been dspnsed to strengthen its claim by further act
Of posseesion. In the mean time. between the FL
reign ministers IF the United States and Great Br
tain there has been constant correspondence, q

full articles.headline: Vo. 63.
full articles.article:
mutual forbearance, of the expediency Of the pre-
scrvation of the same state of things in the disputed
territory as existed at the date Of the Treaty Of
Client, and of avoiding all disputes which might
grow ont of the agitation OF it.


With respect to the two governments, there is
perfectly good understanding, upon the obvious pro-
priety, and indeed necessity. Of forbearance and
moderation on both sides. as to this question. Any
acts of contrary character are acts OF individual
citizens, without the authority sanction OF either
government and, Of course, are to be avoided and
rebuked.
This is the general state of the facts. As to the
particular case of Gen. Baker, referred to by the
Albion, we can only say, that if he stopped the mail
and did other obnoxious acts, son what is techni-
cay and practically British territory" by which we
understand such territory was in possion OF Great
Britain at the date of the Treaty of Ghen. and pre-
viously. then he violating what believe to be
the settled understanding between the two govern


ments. and his conduct will, Of course, receive no
countenancc the part of the United States
Whether he was on that territory not, is aques.
tion which depends upon evidence not within our
reach


We hope we have answered the question Of the
Albion satisfactorily. We will only add. that we
believe that measures will be taken, on the part Of


the United States to ascertain the true character OF


the transactions on the disputed territory, there


being disposition here to connIvc at any acts OF


violence, contrary to the understanding which exists


between Great Britain and the United States on this


subject.


| BANKS.--The number Of Banking institutions


in the United States, of all kinds, good bad and IN"


different is $50, (Which add thervarous branches,


and they will amount TO 600. OF this number


eighty are on the list of broken banks. All the Ken


lucky, Tennessee, Illinois, and Missouri banks are


of this class and those of Alabama are but little bet


ter. Maine has 23 banks, of which are broken:
Vermont 81 New w-Hampshre 90; Massachusetts

good, and we should think good for nothing Con-


necticut l6--2 broken Newly ork 55-7 broken:

broken District of Columbia 15-3 broken; Vir-
ginia and l5 branches n. and s. Carolina 20;

Considering the great number OF these institutions


scattered over the whole country, and using so ma.


ny different modes of engravngs, il is not surprising
that counterfeiting has become SO frequent. One
eighth of the convicts at Auburn, are confined for


this crime. The number of detected counterfeters
is about 24O the amount yearly put in circulation


is estimated at t,oo millions; the loss no doubt falls
principally upon the poorer class. for they are the


least able to detect them; some plan ought therea
fore to be devised to prevent this enormous deficit
in the proceeds of their hard earnings Maine and

full articles.headline:
From the Providence Gazette.
THE FROGS OF WINUEFANr.
full articles.article:
II" Oto Co'ohy 1hte-.J0nhden on 1dct.
WHEN these free states were colonies
Unto the mother nation,
And in Connecticut the good
Old Blue Laws were in fashion,
A circumstance which there occur'd
And much the mind surprises
Upon rehecton) then gave rise
To many strange surmises.
You all have seen, as presume,
Or had chance to see
These strange amphibious quadrupeds,
Call'd Bull-Frogs commonly
Well, in Connecticut 'ts said


By those who make pretensions
To truth, these creatures often grow
To marvellous dimensions.
One night in July '5s


They left their home behind 'cm,
Which was an oak and chesnut swamp
About FIVE miles from Windham.
The cause was this the summers sun
Had dried their pond away there
So shallow, that, TO save their souls,
The Bull-Frogs could not stay there.
SO, in regiment they hoppd,
With many curious antic,
Along the road which led unto



The river Minnomantic.
Soon they in sight of Windham came,
All in high perspration,
And held their course tow'rd the same
With loud vociferation.
You know such kind Of creatures are
By nature quite voracious
Thus they, compell'd by hunger, were
Remarkably loquacious.
Up flew the windows one and all,
And then with ears erected,
From every easement gaping rows
Ofnight-cap'd heads projected.
The children cried, the women scream'd,
60 Lord have mercy on us
The French have come to burn us out,
And now are close upon u.s."
A few, upon the first alarm,


Then armed themselves TO go forth
Against the foe, with guns and belts,
Shot, Powder-horns, and so forth.
Soon all were running here and there,
In mighty CONSERVATION,
Resolved of the town to make


quick evacuation.
Away they went across the lots,


Hats, caps and wigs were scatter'd,
And heads were broke, and shoes were lost,
Shins bruis'tl and noses batter'd.
Thus, having gain'd mile or two,


These men ofsteady habits,
All snug behind an old stone wall,


Lay like nest of rabbits.
And in this state, for half an hour,


With Jaws an inch assunder,
They thought upon their goods at home,
Expos'd to lawess punder.
They thought upon their helpless wives,
Their meeting house and cattle,
And then resolved to sally forth


And give the Frenchmen battle.
Among the property which they


Had bro't with them to saveit,
Were found two trumpets and drum,


Just as good luck would have it.
Fifteen or twenty iewsharps then


Were found in good condition,
And all the longest winded men


Were put in requlslton.
Straichtway, in long and loud alarm,


Said instruments were clang-ed,
And the good old one hundredth psalm


From nose and jewsharp twang-ed.
Such as we're armed in order ranged,


The music in the centre,
Declar'd they would not run away,


But on the French would venture.
There might have been among them all


Say twenty guns or over
How many pitch-forks, scythes and Halls


never could discover.


The rest agreed to close the rear,


After some intercesson-
And all together made queer
And curious procession.
Some were persuaded that they saw
The band of French maranders,
And not few declared they heard
The officers give orders.
These words could be distinguished then,
Dyer Hellerkln, and Fete ) ;,
And when they heard the last, they though


The French desired treaty
Co three GOOD sober minded men
